body: But the document doesn't say that...
Which document says something not provided? If it doesn't exist on the document, but it is not a feature.
I am going to merge this first, @ascrutae please deploy this on the demo env, and let's see how this works in days.

> 1、Add variable `private static string role` in `OAPNodeChecker`, and set it in `CoreModuleProvider#start` stage
> 2、check `private static string role` before `CoreModuleProvider#isHealth` check itself

Basically, I think it is reasonable. You could try a pull request about this.
Use English on the GitHub.
Please read the document before submitting an issue, http://skywalking.apache.org/docs/main/v8.4.0/en/faq/hour-day-metrics-stopping/

Why are you openning issue for no detail?
Think in this way, period is windows of metric slot. Count means how many slots over the threshold in the given window.

According to description in this link:
https://github.com/apache/skywalking/blob/9268b987afd35ed6b0b963758bfd7d55c0916b23/docs/en/FAQ/vnode.md
"The UI real check the parent spans and reference segments of all spans, if a parent id(segment id + span id) can't be found, then it creates a VNode automatically."
But, I found that many of the normal spans(it's father-span can be accurately identified) could not be loaded and displayed either.
Here's the data(data from Chrom's "Network"), the first two are the normal display of the span for comparison, the last one is a span with normal data but not displayed.

> Why are you openning issue for no detail?

I'm preparing descriptions and data

You should use rocketbot ui to debug locally. 
We can see at our side, the spans are connected correctly, if you are not, we would recommend you to debug first.
Sum requires a value as parameter. I remember there is a wrong in the doc, and has been fixed in the latest.

@wu-sheng So,how cat i define a metric to do the same thing like this:
endpoint_abnormal = from(Endpoint.*).filter(responseCode in [404, 500, 503]).sum()
Are you meaning count?
@wu-sheng yes
Use count function. Sum means add the value of a field.

How to understand _how many slots_? Take response time as an example. When the application throughput is relatively high, there are hundreds of requests per second, and each request has a response time. Does each request count as a count?
In the storage, all metrics have been downsampling into minutes. Such as CPM in 21:54 is one slot, the next is 21:55. What is your traffic load, doesn't matter.

4G is not a big memory set. and your stack shows, there are a lot of ES Request instances, which means your ElasticSearch can't support the traffic, so many things are hold in the memory.  
We have a size threshold for the queues, but still, you could leak considering you only have 4G memory.

I can see you also submit the same one on the pinpoint side, I am not sure what is your agenda, but basically, the open-source community is not the right place to ask for commercial support. Connect to the people you want to ask.
This place is for open source collaboration.
https://github.com/pinpoint-apm/pinpoint/issues/7732 is the one you submitted.
How to set the size of the queue to avoid OOM。
First of all, 4G is really not suitable for product env. The current queue size is 20k elements(max) per metric. It is a static setting, rather than a configuration.
What is the recommended setting。

@EvanLjp Back to you, have you tried to change `PersistenceTimer#extractDataAndSave`'s execution stage into the concurrency mode, such as using 2-4 threads to compare the performance? The 20s seem a little long.
Base on your throughput, at least 8G or 16G, even above. OAP server could process 100k+ traces/s easily, but you need to make sure, your ES server and memory are enough

My ES can support 100W/s writes, and my oap runs in kubernetes. I want to run multi-pod, small (2G, 4G) OAPserver, because this way I can make better use of fragmented resources. At present, I It's useless to encounter the performance problem of writing ES, but the problem of OAPserver GC AND OOM。
let me have a try.

You have a huge number of ES update objects, read the memory table you posted yourself. It shows very clear. I am doubting the performance of your ES. 
Anyway, that is your env, I(we) can't and shouldn't touch. I just provide information to help. You need to do deep analysis.
